english_translation: Narrated by Sahl ibn Sa'd al-Sa'idi: Two times are there during which the gates of heaven are opened and few are the supplicants whose supplication is not answered - at the time of the call to prayer and during the row (of fighters) in the way of Allah.

narrators.name: Yahya
narrators.alternative_names: Abu Zakariyyah al-Tamimi

narrators.name: Malik
narrators.full_name: Malik ibn Anas ibn Malik ibn Abi Amir al-Asbahi
narrators.alternative_names: Imam Malik, Maliki

narrators.name: Abu Hazim
narrators.full_name: Salman ibn Dinar al-Ashja'i, known as Abu Hazim
narrators.alternative_names: Salman ibn Dinar

narrators.name: Sahl ibn Sa'd
narrators.full_name: Sahl ibn Sa'd ibn Malik al-Sa'idi al-Ansari
narrators.alternative_names: Abu al-Hasan al-Sa'idi

narrators.name: Prophet Muhammad ﷺ
narrators.full_name: Muhammad ibn Abdullah ibn Abd al-Muttalib ibn Hashim al-Hashimi al-Qurashi
narrators.alternative_names: Ahmad, al-Mustafa, al-Rasul

chainIssues: Multiple instances of عَنْ ('an) transmission from reliable narrators without explicit direct hearing terms, but all narrators are highly trustworthy

potential_issues.issue: Use of عَنْ ('an) in chain transmission
potential_issues.impact: While عَنْ typically indicates potentially ambiguous transmission, all narrators in this chain (Malik, Abu Hazim, Sahl ibn Sa'd) are highly reliable and known for accuracy. This does not significantly affect authenticity given the caliber of transmitters.

potential_issues.issue: First narrator identity not explicitly stated in the text
potential_issues.impact: Though Yahya ibn Yahya is traditionally identified as the collector of Muwatta' narrations, the text only shows 'He narrated to me'. This is a minor documentation issue as convention identifies this as Yahya.

Topics: Times when the gates of heaven are opened for supplication
Acceptance of supplication at the time of the call to prayer
Acceptance of supplication during the row of fighters in the way of Allah

english_translation: Narrated by Malik: It reached him that the muezzin came to Umar ibn al-Khattab to call him for the dawn prayer and found him sleeping. He said: 'Prayer is better than sleep.' Umar ordered him to put this phrase in the call to the dawn prayer.

narrators.name: Yahya
narrators.alternative_names: Abu Zakariyyah al-Tamimi

narrators.name: Malik
narrators.full_name: Malik ibn Anas ibn Malik ibn Abi Amir al-Asbahi
narrators.alternative_names: Imam Malik

narrators.name: Unknown source
narrators.transmissionTermMeaning: It reached him (indicates mursal transmission - indirect/broken chain)

narrators.name: Umar ibn al-Khattab
narrators.full_name: Umar ibn al-Khattab ibn Nufayl al-Qurashi al-Adawi
narrators.alternative_names: al-Faruq

chainIssues: Critical issue: Uses بَلَغَهُ (it reached him) indicating mursal transmission with broken chain. The immediate source between Malik and Umar is not identified, making this a disconnected report.

potential_issues.issue: Mursal transmission (بَلَغَهُ) with unidentified intermediate link
potential_issues.impact: Malik does not explicitly name the source from whom this report reached him. This indicates a mursal transmission which weakens the chain as we cannot verify the reliability of the missing narrator(s) between Malik and the actual event.

potential_issues.issue: Story attributed to Umar ibn al-Khattab without direct chain
potential_issues.impact: While Umar is highly reliable, the broken chain means we cannot directly verify when and how he performed or commanded this action, only that this report reached Malik indirectly.

IISGrade: Disconnections But All Narrators Are Ok
Topics: Incident of the muezzin calling Umar ibn al-Khattab for the dawn prayer
Phrase 'Prayer is better than sleep' in the morning call to prayer
Umar ibn al-Khattab's instruction regarding the call to prayer

english_translation: Narrated by Abu Suhayl ibn Malik from his father: 'I do not know of anything from what I found the people upon except the call to prayer.' And narrated: That Abdullah ibn Umar heard the call while he was at al-Baqi' and he hastened to walk to the mosque.

narrators.name: Yahya
narrators.alternative_names: Abu Zakariyyah

narrators.name: Malik
narrators.full_name: Malik ibn Anas ibn Malik ibn Abi Amir al-Asbahi
narrators.alternative_names: Imam Malik

narrators.name: Abu Suhayl
narrators.full_name: Muhammad ibn Abdullah ibn Hafas ibn Hisham ibn Zayd ibn Anas ibn Malik al-Ansari
narrators.alternative_names: Abu Suhayl al-Ansar

narrators.name: Malik ibn Sahl
narrators.full_name: Malik ibn Sahl ibn Malik al-Ansari al-Sa'idi
narrators.alternative_names: Father of Abu Suhayl

chainIssues: Chain uses عَنْ ('an) transmission terms consistently; however all narrators are highly reliable with no known tadlis

narrators.name: Yahya
narrators.alternative_names: Abu Zakariyyah

narrators.alternative_names: Ibn Umar

chainIssues: Chain uses عَنْ ('an) and أَنَّ (anna) transmission terms; all narrators are highly reliable with exceptional status

potential_issues.issue: Use of عَنْ ('an) and أَنَّ (anna) in otherwise highly reliable chain
potential_issues.impact: While these transmission terms can indicate ambiguity, the narrators involved (Malik, Nafi', Abdullah ibn Umar) are all of exceptional reliability and not known for tadlis. The use of these terms does not significantly weaken the hadith given the high caliber of transmitters.

potential_issues.issue: Second chain attributes narration to Abdullah ibn Umar without explicit statement from Prophet ﷺ
potential_issues.impact: The hadith records Abdullah ibn Umar's action of hastening to the mosque upon hearing the call, which is a mawquf report of a companion's practice rather than a marfu' statement from the Prophet.

Topics: Statement of Malik's father about the call to prayer
Incident of Abdullah ibn Umar hastening to the mosque upon hearing the call to prayer
Response to the call to prayer
Attention and obedience to the call to prayer

english_translation: Chapter heading: The Call to Prayer While Traveling and Without Ablution

potential_issues.issue: This is a chapter heading, not a hadith
potential_issues.impact: No chain of transmission or hadith text exists. This is editorial content marking the beginning of a new topic section.

Topics: Chapter on the call to prayer while traveling
Call to prayer without ablution

english_translation: Narrated by Nafi': Abdullah ibn Umar called the Adhan (call to prayer) on a cold and windy night and said: 'Pray in your dwellings.' Then he said: 'Indeed the Messenger of Allah ﷺ used to command the muezzin when it was a cold night with rain to say: Pray in your dwellings.'

narrators.name: Yahya
narrators.alternative_names: Abu Zakariyyah

narrators.name: Malik
narrators.full_name: Malik ibn Anas ibn Malik ibn Abi Amir al-Asbahi
narrators.alternative_names: Imam Malik

narrators.name: Nafi'
narrators.full_name: Nafi' ibn al-Harith al-Laythi, mawla of Abdullah ibn Umar
narrators.alternative_names: Nafi' the mawla of Ibn Umar

narrators.name: Abdullah ibn Umar
narrators.full_name: Abdullah ibn Umar ibn al-Khattab al-Qurashi al-Adawi
narrators.alternative_names: Ibn Umar

narrators.name: Prophet Muhammad ﷺ
narrators.full_name: Muhammad ibn Abdullah ibn Abd al-Muttalib ibn Hashim al-Hashimi al-Qurashi
narrators.alternative_names: Ahmad, al-Mustafa

chainIssues: Use of عَنْ ('an) and أَنَّ (anna) transmission terms; however all narrators are of exceptional reliability

potential_issues.issue: Use of عَنْ and أَنَّ in transmission chain
potential_issues.impact: These indirect transmission terms are used, but given the exceptional reliability of all narrators (Malik, Nafi', Abdullah ibn Umar) and their lack of known tadlis, this does not significantly impact the hadith's authenticity.

potential_issues.issue: Hadith is reported through Abdullah ibn Umar's practice and statement
potential_issues.impact: The hadith comes to us through Abdullah ibn Umar's narration of the Prophet's ﷺ instruction, making it a second-hand account of a Prophetic directive rather than a direct report.

Topics: Incident of Abdullah ibn Umar announcing the call to prayer on a cold windy night
Permission to pray in dwellings during harsh weather
Prophet's ﷺ instruction to announce permission to pray at home during cold and rainy nights

english_translation: Narrated by Nafi': Abdullah ibn Umar did not increase the Iqamah beyond that done during travel except in the dawn prayer, for he would call the Adhan for it and perform the Iqamah. And he used to say: 'The Adhan is only for the Imam under whom the people gather.'

narrators.name: Yahya
narrators.alternative_names: Abu Zakariyyah

narrators.name: Malik
narrators.full_name: Malik ibn Anas ibn Malik ibn Abi Amir al-Asbahi
narrators.alternative_names: Imam Malik

narrators.name: Nafi'
narrators.full_name: Nafi' ibn al-Harith al-Laythi, mawla of Abdullah ibn Umar
narrators.alternative_names: Nafi' the mawla of Ibn Umar

narrators.name: Abdullah ibn Umar
narrators.full_name: Abdullah ibn Umar ibn al-Khattab al-Qurashi al-Adawi
narrators.alternative_names: Ibn Umar

chainIssues: Use of عَنْ and أَنَّ transmission terms throughout chain, but all narrators are highly reliable

potential_issues.issue: Use of أَنَّ (anna) indicating indirect transmission
potential_issues.impact: The hadith reports Abdullah ibn Umar's practice and statement using أَنَّ, which is acceptable given his exceptional reliability and Nafi''s direct transmission from him.

potential_issues.issue: Mawquf hadith - report of companion's practice and opinion
potential_issues.impact: This is a mawquf report recording Abdullah ibn Umar's understanding and practice regarding the call to prayer during travel, not a statement attributed to the Prophet ﷺ.

Topics: Abdullah ibn Umar's practice regarding the call to prayer and standing during travel
Exception for the dawn prayer regarding the call to prayer
Statement of Abdullah ibn Umar about the call to prayer being for the imam who gathers the people

english_translation: Narrated by Hisham ibn Urwah from his father Urwah: When you are traveling, if you wish you may call the Adhan and perform the Iqamah, and if you wish you may only perform the Iqamah without the Adhan. And Yahya said: I heard Malik saying: There is no harm in calling the Adhan while riding.

narrators.name: Yahya
narrators.alternative_names: Abu Zakariyyah

narrators.name: Malik
narrators.full_name: Malik ibn Anas ibn Malik ibn Abi Amir al-Asbahi
narrators.alternative_names: Imam Malik

narrators.name: Hisham ibn Urwah
narrators.full_name: Hisham ibn Urwah ibn al-Zubayr al-Asadi
narrators.alternative_names: Abu al-Mundhir al-Mawsili

narrators.name: Urwah ibn al-Zubayr
narrators.full_name: Urwah ibn al-Zubayr ibn al-Awwam al-Asadi
narrators.alternative_names: Abu Abd al-Malik

chainIssues: Transmission uses عَنْ consistently but all narrators are highly reliable

potential_issues.issue: Use of عَنْ transmission throughout the chain
potential_issues.impact: While عَنْ could indicate ambiguous transmission, all narrators (Malik, Hisham ibn Urwah, Urwah) are known for precision and reliability, mitigating this concern.

potential_issues.issue: Hadith reports Urwah ibn al-Zubayr's instruction to his son
potential_issues.impact: This is a mawquf report of a companion's teaching on the call to prayer during travel, not an explicit statement attributed to the Prophet ﷺ.

Topics: Teaching of Urwah ibn al-Zubayr on the call to prayer while traveling
Permission to call the Adhan and perform Iqamah or perform only Iqamah during travel
Permission to call the Adhan while riding

english_translation: Narrated by Sa'id ibn al-Musayyab: Whoever prays in an empty barren land has an angel praying at his right side and an angel at his left side. So when he calls the Adhan and performs the Iqamah or only performs the Iqamah, there pray behind him from the angels those alike the mountains.

narrators.name: Yahya
narrators.alternative_names: Abu Zakariyyah

narrators.name: Malik
narrators.full_name: Malik ibn Anas ibn Malik ibn Abi Amir al-Asbahi
narrators.alternative_names: Imam Malik

narrators.name: Yahya ibn Sa'id
narrators.full_name: Yahya ibn Sa'id ibn Qays al-Ansari
narrators.alternative_names: al-Qadi al-Imam

narrators.name: Sa'id ibn al-Musayyab
narrators.full_name: Sa'id ibn al-Musayyab ibn Hazn al-Makhzumi
narrators.alternative_names: al-Faqih al-A'zam

chainIssues: Chain uses عَنْ transmission terms throughout; however all narrators are of exceptional reliability

potential_issues.issue: Use of عَنْ transmission from highly reliable narrators
potential_issues.impact: Despite using عَنْ, all narrators (Malik, Yahya ibn Sa'id, Sa'id ibn al-Musayyab) are among the most reliable and known for precision. This does not significantly weaken the chain.

potential_issues.issue: Mawquf report from Sa'id ibn al-Musayyab
potential_issues.impact: This is a statement attributed to a tabi'i (second generation) companion-follower rather than the Prophet ﷺ, though it discusses angelic accompaniment in prayer.

Topics: Statement of Sa'id ibn al-Musayyab regarding angels in prayer
Angels praying alongside an individual in desolate lands
Angels multiplying in numbers when Adhan is called and Iqamah is performed

english_translation: Chapter heading: The Timing of the Pre-Dawn Meal (Suhur) in relation to the Call to Prayer

potential_issues.issue: This is a chapter heading, not a hadith
potential_issues.impact: No chain of transmission or hadith text exists. This is editorial content.

Topics: Chapter on timing of pre-dawn meal (Suhur) and the call to prayer

english_translation: Narrated by Abdullah ibn Umar: The Messenger of Allah ﷺ said: Indeed Bilal calls the Adhan at night, so eat and drink until Ibn Umm Maktum calls the Adhan.

narrators.name: Yahya
narrators.alternative_names: Abu Zakariyyah

narrators.name: Malik
narrators.full_name: Malik ibn Anas ibn Malik ibn Abi Amir al-Asbahi
narrators.alternative_names: Imam Malik

narrators.name: Abdullah ibn Dinar
narrators.alternative_names: Abu Abd al-Rahman al-'Umari

narrators.name: Abdullah ibn Umar
narrators.full_name: Abdullah ibn Umar ibn al-Khattab al-Qurashi al-Adawi
narrators.alternative_names: Ibn Umar

narrators.name: Prophet Muhammad ﷺ
narrators.full_name: Muhammad ibn Abdullah ibn Abd al-Muttalib ibn Hashim al-Hashimi al-Qurashi
narrators.alternative_names: Ahmad, al-Mustafa

chainIssues: Chain uses عَنْ transmission; however all narrators are highly reliable

potential_issues.issue: Use of عَنْ transmission terms in chain
potential_issues.impact: Although عَنْ is used, the narrators (Malik, Abdullah ibn Dinar, Abdullah ibn Umar) are all of exceptional reliability. Abdullah ibn Dinar is known for precision in transmitting from Ibn Umar.

potential_issues.issue: Hadith transmitted through Abdullah ibn Umar
potential_issues.impact: The hadith is reported from the Prophet ﷺ through Abdullah ibn Umar, making it a second-hand report from a companion.

Topics: Statement of the Prophet ﷺ regarding Bilal calling the Adhan at night
Permission to eat and drink during pre-dawn hours until the true dawn call
Bilal and Ibn Umm Maktum as the muezzins of the Prophet ﷺ

english_translation: Narrated by Salem ibn Abdullah from Ibn Shihab al-Zuhri: The Messenger of Allah ﷺ said: Indeed Bilal calls the Adhan at night, so eat and drink until Ibn Umm Maktum calls the Adhan. Ibn Umm Maktum was a blind man who would not call unless it was said to him: The morning has come, the morning has come.

narrators.name: Yahya
narrators.alternative_names: Abu Zakariyyah

narrators.name: Malik
narrators.full_name: Malik ibn Anas ibn Malik ibn Abi Amir al-Asbahi
narrators.alternative_names: Imam Malik

narrators.name: Ibn Shihab al-Zuhri
narrators.full_name: Muhammad ibn Muslim ibn Shihab al-Zuhri
reliabilityIssues: mudallis - Category 1-2 (acceptable even with indirect transmission)
narrators.alternative_names: al-Imam al-Hafiz

narrators.name: Salem ibn Abdullah
narrators.full_name: Salem ibn Abdullah ibn Umar ibn al-Khattab al-Qurashi al-Adawi
narrators.alternative_names: Abu Umar

narrators.name: Prophet Muhammad ﷺ
narrators.full_name: Muhammad ibn Abdullah ibn Abd al-Muttalib ibn Hashim al-Hashimi al-Qurashi
narrators.alternative_names: Ahmad, al-Mustafa

chainIssues: Ibn Shihab al-Zuhri is known for tadlis (Category 1-2) and uses عَنْ, but he is highly reliable and such tadlis does not affect acceptance per majority of hadith scholars

potential_issues.issue: Ibn Shihab al-Zuhri is classified as a mudallis (Category 1-2) by Ibn Hajar
potential_issues.impact: While al-Zuhri is known to occasionally practice tadlis, scholars classify him as Category 1-2 which means his transmissions are generally acceptable. His exceptional reliability and precision mitigate concerns even when using عَنْ.

potential_issues.issue: Multiple instances of عَنْ transmission
potential_issues.impact: The chain consistently uses عَنْ, but all narrators (Malik, al-Zuhri, Salem ibn Abdullah) are highly reliable and known for precision.

potential_issues.issue: Additional contextual information about Ibn Umm Maktum's blindness
potential_issues.impact: The hadith adds information about Ibn Umm Maktum being blind and needing to be told 'the morning has come,' which contextualizes why his call would be used as the definitive signal for the start of the fast.

Topics: Statement of the Prophet ﷺ about Bilal calling the Adhan at night
Permission to eat and drink until Ibn Umm Maktum calls the Adhan
Incident about Ibn Umm Maktum being blind and requiring notification of dawn
The two muezzins of the Prophet ﷺ - Bilal and Ibn Umm Maktum
